title.value: Root phosphatase activity is coordinated with the root conservation gradient across a phosphorus gradient in a lowland tropical forest
title.justification: Title from the provided research paper.
title.quote: Root phosphatase activity is coordinated with the root conservation gradient across a phosphorus gradient in a lowland tropical forest

extractions.description: The paper investigates the coordination of root phosphatase activity with various root traits along a phosphorus availability gradient in tropical forests. Using measurements of root traits such as root diameter, specific root length, root tissue density, and nitrogen concentration among others, it aims to understand how different tree species adapt their phosphorus acquisition strategies to varying levels of soil phosphorus.

type.justification: The study involves measurements, data collection, and analysis of root traits and soil phosphorus levels across different tropical forest sites.
type.quote: We measured root PME activity and commonly-measured root traits, including root diameter, specific root length (SRL), root tissue density (RTD), and nitrogen concentration ([N]) in 18 co-occurring trees across soils with varying P availability to better understand trees response to P supply.

name.justification: The research focuses on plant root traits and their phosphorus acquisition strategies in tropical forests.
name.quote: Soil phosphorus (P) is a growth-limiting nutrient in tropical ecosystems, driving diverse P-acquisition strategies among plants.

name.justification: The study involves ecological concepts such as soil nutrient availability, plant adaptation, and species distribution.
name.quote: Overall, our study aimed to improve our understanding of P-acquisition strategies deployed by co-occurring tropical tree species, focusing on P acquisition traits that may represent diagnostic indicators of fertility, in order to better explain tropical tree species distributions across edaphic gradients.

name.justification: The research includes extensive analysis of soil phosphorus levels and their impact on root traits.
name.quote: Soil PME activity tends to increase with declining soil P supply (Allison et al., 2007; Margalef et al., 2017). Similarly, mycorrhizal plant species are expected to follow a general pattern whereby they rely more heavily on mycorrhizal partners for nutrient acquisition as P supply declines (Treseder, 2004; Ma et al., 2021).

name.value: Roots and Soil Samples from Central Panama
name.justification: The study measured root traits and soil phosphorus levels from various tree species in central Panama.
name.quote: Our study adds key root traits of the RES and less commonly measured traits such as root branching intensity, root hair length and density to previously measured PME activity on the most abundant co-occurring trees across sites in central Panama differing strongly in total and exchangeable P (Guilbeault-Mayers et al., 2020).

referenced_paper_title.value: Greater root phosphatase activity of tropical trees at low phosphorus despite strong variation among species.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper provided previous measurements of PME activity used in this study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Further details of root PME assay methods can be found in our previous study at the same sites (Guilbeault-Mayers et al., 2020).
